definitions: throw something carelessly or with considerable force in a specified direction
get rid of something unwanted or give up on something decisively
touch someone playfully or affectionately under the chin with gentle upward motion
examples: She chucked the ball across the yard to her dog
The kids were chucking stones into the lake all afternoon
He finally chucked his old running shoes in the trash
She decided to chuck her corporate job and travel the world
The grandmother chucked the baby under the chin lovingly
He chucked her chin playfully before leaving for work

definitions: divide something into thick pieces or substantial parts for easier handling or processing
organize information or data into meaningful groups or segments for improved understanding or processing
examples: The chef chunked the vegetables for the hearty stew
She chunked the large text into smaller paragraphs for clarity
The software chunks data into manageable blocks for transmission
Students learn better when teachers chunk complex information into sections

definitions: agitate milk or cream vigorously to make butter or mix something with forceful circular motion
produce something rapidly and continuously often with emphasis on quantity over quality
move about violently or experience turbulent motion like disturbed water or churning stomach
experience frequent changes in personnel or customers leaving and being replaced in business
examples: She churned the cream until it turned into fresh butter
The machine churned the mixture for thirty minutes straight
The factory churns out thousands of products every single day
Hollywood studios churn out sequels to maximize their profits
The stormy sea churned violently against the rocky coastline
His stomach churned nervously before the important job interview
The company churns through employees at an alarming annual rate
Subscription services work hard to reduce their customer churn rate

definitions: descend or cause to descend rapidly through a chute or similar sloped channel
examples: The packages chute down to the sorting area below
Workers chute the laundry down to the basement washing facility

definitions: convert a message into secret code or decode an encrypted message using systematic methods
work out mathematical calculations or solve numerical problems through systematic computation
examples: The spy ciphered the message before sending it to headquarters
Intelligence officers spent hours trying to cipher the intercepted communications
The accountant ciphered the complex calculations for the annual report
Students learned to cipher basic arithmetic problems without using calculators

definitions: move around something in a circular path or orbit maintaining roughly equal distance from center
surround or encircle something completely forming a boundary or protective barrier around it
draw a circle around something to mark highlight or identify it for special attention
examples: The plane circled the airport waiting for clearance to land
Hawks circle high above looking for prey in the fields
Police officers circled the building to prevent anyone from escaping
The wolves circled their prey before moving in for attack
Please circle the correct answers on your test paper
The editor circled all the spelling errors in red ink

definitions: travel around a defined route or area typically returning to the starting point in regular pattern
examples: The judge circuits through three counties during each monthly session
Sales representatives circuit the region visiting all their major clients

definitions: move continuously through a closed system or space in a regular pattern like blood or air
distribute or pass something around among many people or places for widespread access
move around at a social event to interact with many different people or groups
examples: Blood circulates through the body delivering oxygen to all tissues
Fresh air circulates through the ventilation system every few minutes
The teacher circulated the handouts to all students in class
Rumors about the merger circulated quickly throughout the company
The host circulated among guests making sure everyone felt welcome
Politicians circulate at fundraising events to meet potential donors

definitions: sail or travel completely around something especially the world or a large landmass by water
find a way around an obstacle or problem through clever maneuvering or alternative approaches
examples: Magellan's crew was first to circumnavigate the globe successfully
The yacht took two years to circumnavigate the entire continent
The lawyer circumnavigated the legal restrictions with creative contract language
Companies often try to circumnavigate tax laws through offshore accounts

definitions: find a way to avoid or get around restrictions rules or problems through clever means
go around a physical obstacle or barrier rather than going through or over it
examples: Hackers constantly try to circumvent security systems to access data
The company circumvented regulations by operating in international waters
Hikers had to circumvent the flooded trail by taking another path
The army circumvented enemy defenses by attacking from the rear

definitions: quote or reference a source of information as evidence or support for a statement or argument
officially summon someone to appear in court or issue a legal notice for violation
formally mention someone for official commendation or recognition of outstanding service or achievement
examples: The researcher cited numerous studies to support her groundbreaking hypothesis
Students must cite all sources properly in their academic papers
The officer cited the driver for speeding and reckless driving
The company was cited for multiple safety violations by inspectors
The general cited three soldiers for bravery during the battle
The mayor cited several citizens for their exceptional community service

definitions: make a sharp short sound when hard surfaces strike together repeatedly or abruptly
examples: Her high heels clacked loudly on the marble floor
The typewriter keys clacked as she typed the urgent report

definitions: state or assert that something is true typically without providing immediate proof or evidence
demand something as a rightful possession or assert one's right to something legally or formally
cause the loss of someone's life particularly through disaster accident or disease
examples: She claims to have witnessed the entire incident firsthand
The company claims their product is completely environmentally friendly
He claimed his inheritance after his father's death last year
Passengers can claim compensation for delayed flights over three hours
The earthquake claimed over five hundred lives in the region
Cancer claims millions of lives worldwide every single year

definitions: suddenly stop talking or refuse to speak especially when questioned or under pressure
examples: The witness clammed up when asked about the suspect
Children often clam up when meeting strangers for the first time

definitions: loudly and insistently demand something or express strong desire for something publicly
make a loud confused noise especially from many voices or sources at once
examples: Protesters clamored for justice outside the courthouse all day
Fans clamored for tickets to the championship game
The crowd clamored so loudly that speakers couldn't be heard
Birds clamored in the trees at dawn disturbing our sleep

definitions: fasten or fix something in position using a clamp or similar device to hold firmly
take strict action to suppress or prevent something considered undesirable or threatening
examples: The carpenter clamped the wood pieces together while the glue dried
Surgeons clamped the artery to stop the bleeding immediately
The government clamped down on illegal immigration last year
Police clamped down on street racing after several accidents

definitions: make a loud sharp metallic sound when metal objects strike together or against hard surfaces
examples: The prisoner's chains clanked as he walked down the corridor
Tools clanked in the toolbox as the truck bounced over potholes

definitions: strike the palms of hands together repeatedly to show approval or attract attention
place or put something somewhere quickly and forcefully with sudden decisive movement
produce a sudden loud explosive sound like thunder during a storm
examples: The audience clapped enthusiastically after the brilliant performance
Teachers clap their hands to get students' attention quickly
He clapped his hand over her mouth to keep her quiet
She clapped the book shut when someone entered the room
Thunder clapped overhead making everyone jump in surprise
Lightning flashed and thunder clapped throughout the stormy night

definitions: make a statement or situation clearer and easier to understand by explaining in more detail
make a liquid clear by removing unwanted solid matter through heating or filtering
examples: The professor clarified the complex concept with several helpful examples
Please clarify your position on this important policy issue
The chef clarified the butter by removing all milk solids
The laboratory technician clarified the solution through careful filtration

definitions: come into violent physical conflict or collision with opposing forces or groups
have a serious disagreement or incompatible difference of opinion with someone
look unpleasant together because colors patterns or styles do not match harmoniously
examples: Protesters clashed with police during the demonstration downtown yesterday
The two armies clashed at dawn in the decisive battle
Board members clashed over the proposed budget cuts repeatedly
Their personalities clash whenever they work on projects together
That orange shirt clashes horribly with your green pants
The modern furniture clashes with the Victorian architectural style

definitions: grasp or hold something or someone tightly with hands or arms showing affection or security
fasten or secure something with a clasp or similar device to keep it closed
examples: She clasped her mother's hand during the scary movie
The child clasped his favorite teddy bear while sleeping
She clasped the necklace around her neck before the party
He clasped the briefcase shut and headed to the meeting

definitions: arrange things systematically in classes or categories according to shared characteristics or criteria
officially designate information or documents as secret and limit access to authorized personnel
examples: Scientists classify organisms based on their evolutionary relationships
Libraries classify books using the Dewey Decimal System
The government classified the documents as top secret immediately
Military officials classified the operation details for national security

definitions: scratch tear or dig with claws or fingernails often causing damage or injury
struggle desperately to achieve or obtain something through intense persistent effort
examples: The cat clawed the furniture leaving deep scratches everywhere
She clawed at the attacker's face in self defense
He clawed his way to the top of the company
The team clawed back from a twenty point deficit

definitions: remove dirt marks or unwanted substances from something by washing wiping or brushing
make a place neat and orderly by removing clutter and organizing items properly
acquire all of someone's money or possessions especially through gambling or theft
examples: She cleaned the windows until they sparkled in sunlight
The janitor cleans the office building every evening thoroughly
Please clean your room before your friends come over
We need to clean the garage this weekend
The casino cleaned him out in just three hours
Thieves cleaned out the store during the night

definitions: clean something thoroughly especially to remove impurities or make ceremonially or spiritually pure
rid the body or system of toxins or harmful substances through special diet or treatment
examples: The priest cleansed the sacred vessels before the ceremony
She cleansed her face with a gentle botanical cleanser
Many people cleanse their bodies with juice fasts periodically
The program cleanses your system of accumulated environmental toxins

definitions: remove unwanted things or obstacles from an area to make space or allow passage
become transparent free from clouds mist or other obscuring elements that block visibility
show that someone is not guilty of something they were accused or suspected of
give official permission or authorization for something to proceed after checking requirements
examples: Workers cleared the debris from the road after the storm
Please clear the table after dinner is finished
The fog cleared by noon revealing mountain views
His confusion cleared after the teacher's explanation
The investigation cleared him of all wrongdoing completely
DNA evidence cleared the suspect after twenty years
Air traffic control cleared the plane for immediate takeoff
Customs cleared our shipment after thorough inspection

definitions: split or divide something especially along a natural line or grain using force
stick firmly and closely to something or remain emotionally attached and loyal
examples: The lumberjack cleaved the log with one powerful swing
The ship's bow cleaved through the icy waters
Children cleave to their parents during frightening situations
She cleaved to her principles despite intense pressure

definitions: work as a clerk performing administrative or sales duties in an office or store
examples: She clerked at the law firm during summer vacation
He clerked for a federal judge after graduating law school

definitions: make a short sharp sound like that of a switch being operated or objects striking
press a button on a computer mouse to select or activate something on screen
suddenly understand or become clear to someone after initial confusion or difficulty
immediately work well together or form a good relationship with natural compatibility
examples: The door clicked shut behind her as she left
Her heels clicked on the polished marble floor
Click the link to download the file immediately
She clicked through dozens of photos on social media
The solution suddenly clicked when she saw the pattern
Everything clicked into place after reading the instructions
The new team members clicked from their first meeting
We clicked instantly and have been friends ever since

definitions: reach the most intense or important point in a series of events or experiences
examples: The symphony climaxed with a powerful crescendo of sound
The protest climaxed when police arrived in riot gear

definitions: move upward typically using hands and feet or with gradual steady effort on steep surfaces
rise to a higher level or increase steadily in amount value or intensity over time
examples: She climbed the mountain despite the dangerous weather conditions
The children love climbing trees in the backyard
Gas prices climbed to record levels this past summer
The company's stock climbed fifty percent in six months

definitions: secure or settle something decisively such as a victory deal or argument beyond doubt
hold someone tightly in an embrace especially in boxing when fighters hold each other
bend over the protruding point of a nail or rivet to secure it firmly
examples: The team clinched the championship with that final goal
She clinched the deal with her impressive presentation
The boxers clinched repeatedly during the intense final round
The lovers clinched in a passionate farewell embrace
The blacksmith clinched the nails to secure the horseshoe
Workers clinched the rivets on the steel beam

definitions: hold on tightly to someone or something with hands or arms for support or security
stick or adhere closely to a surface or object refusing to separate easily
remain emotionally dependent on or faithful to someone something or a belief persistently
examples: The frightened child clung to her mother during the storm
Climbers cling to the rock face with specialized equipment
Wet clothes cling uncomfortably to your body after swimming
The smell of smoke clings to fabric for days
He still clings to outdated beliefs about the world
She clings to hope despite the difficult circumstances

definitions: cut something short or trim with scissors or shears to reduce length or remove parts
fasten or attach things together using a clip or similar fastening device
move at a fast pace or speed especially when describing steady rapid movement
hit or strike someone or something with a sharp quick blow often glancing
examples: She clipped the hedge to keep it neat and tidy
The barber clipped his hair shorter than he wanted
Clip these papers together before filing them away
She clipped the microphone to her lapel before speaking
The horse clipped along at a steady pace
Cars were clipping past at dangerous speeds
The truck clipped the parked car while turning
The boxer clipped his opponent on the chin

definitions: hide conceal or disguise something deliberately to prevent detection or understanding
cover or envelop something completely like a cloak wrapping around a person
examples: The company cloaked its true intentions behind charitable donations
Spies cloaked their activities using elaborate cover stories
Darkness cloaked the forest making navigation nearly impossible
Morning mist cloaked the valley in ethereal beauty

definitions: measure and record the time or speed of something using a timing device
achieve or register a particular time or speed in a measured activity or event
hit someone forcefully especially with a fist in informal or slang usage
examples: The coach clocked each runner during practice yesterday
Officials clocked the wind speed at ninety miles per hour
She clocked her fastest time in the marathon
The car clocked zero to sixty in four seconds
The angry customer clocked the manager in the jaw
He got clocked during the bar fight last night

definitions: block or obstruct a passage pipe or channel preventing normal flow or movement
hinder or impede progress or movement making something slow and difficult
examples: Hair and soap clogged the bathroom drain completely
Fallen leaves clog the gutters every autumn season
Heavy traffic clogs the highways during rush hour
Bureaucracy clogs the system making progress nearly impossible

definitions: seclude or shut away from the outside world especially in a monastery or convent for religious purposes
examples: The monks cloistered themselves for prayer and meditation
She cloistered herself in her study to finish writing

definitions: create an identical genetic copy of an organism or cell through scientific procedures
make an exact copy or duplicate of something especially in computing or technology
examples: Scientists successfully cloned a sheep named Dolly in 1996
Researchers clone cells to study genetic diseases more effectively
Hackers cloned credit cards to steal money from accounts
You can clone your hard drive for backup purposes

definitions: shut someone or oneself away in a private room for confidential discussion or concentrated work
examples: The executives closeted themselves to discuss the merger privately
She closeted herself in her office to prepare the presentation

definitions: bring something to an end or close something permanently such as a business or facility
examples: The company will closure three factories due to declining sales
They decided to closure the investigation after finding no evidence

definitions: form or cause to form into a thick semi-solid mass especially of blood when it coagulates
examples: Blood clots quickly when exposed to air naturally
The medication helps prevent blood from clotting in arteries

definitions: provide someone with clothes or dress someone in particular garments or style
cover or conceal something completely as if wrapping it in cloth or garments
examples: Charities clothe homeless people during cold winter months
Parents must clothe and feed their children properly
Snow clothed the mountains in pristine white beauty
Darkness clothed the landscape in mysterious shadows

definitions: make something unclear confused or less transparent by obscuring vision or understanding
become covered with clouds or filled with gloom losing brightness or clarity
fill or cover an area with clouds smoke or similar obscuring substance
examples: Emotions clouded his judgment during the difficult decision
Steam clouded the bathroom mirror after the hot shower
Her face clouded with anger when she heard the news
The sky clouded over threatening an afternoon storm
Smoke clouded the room making it hard to breathe
Dust clouds the air during desert sandstorms

definitions: hit someone or something hard with the hand or a heavy object
examples: He clouted the ball over the fence for a home run
The boxer clouted his opponent with a powerful right hook

definitions: behave in a silly or foolish way to amuse others or attract attention
perform as a clown entertaining people with comedy and physical humor
examples: Stop clowning around and focus on your homework
He clowned for the cameras at every opportunity
She clowns at children's birthday parties on weekends
Professional clowns train for years to perfect their craft

definitions: strike or beat someone or something with a heavy stick or similar weapon
combine resources or efforts with others to achieve a common goal or purchase
examples: The attacker clubbed the victim with a baseball bat
Hunters clubbed seals during the controversial annual hunt
Neighbors clubbed together to buy playground equipment for the park
We clubbed our money to buy a gift for the teacher

definitions: give someone information about something or help them understand a situation better
examples: Can you clue me in on what happened at the meeting?
She clued him about the surprise party plans accidentally

definitions: form or gather into a thick mass or group things together in clusters
walk with heavy noisy steps making a thumping sound with each footfall
examples: Wet flour clumps together making it hard to mix
Students clumped in groups waiting for the bus
He clumped down the stairs in his heavy boots
The horse clumped along the cobblestone street noisily

definitions: come together or gather in a close group or bunch forming a concentrated collection
examples: Fans clustered around the celebrity seeking autographs eagerly
Houses cluster along the waterfront in this coastal town
